questions.text: Anticoagulant in grey container for glucose estimation is?
questions.solution:
NaF containing vacutainer is grey in colour and commonly used to measure plasma glucose level. NaF is an antiglycolytic agent. It chelates Mg and inhibits enolase enzyme in glycolysis, so stop glycolysis and prevent reduction of sugar which transporting sample to laboratory. Anticoagulant here in grey container is Potassium oxalate.

Option A: Potassium citrate vacutainer is used for culture studies.

Option B: Sodium citrate vacutainer is used for coagulation studies.

Option C: Heparin containing vacutainer is green colour. It is used in estimation of plasma chemistry.

questions.text: Which is not considered in the diagnosis of metabolic syndrome:
questions.solution:
In diagnosing metabolic syndrome, several factors are considered to assess a person's risk for cardiovascular disease and type 2 diabetes. Let's go through each option:

  1. Hip circumference: This is typically measured as part of assessing central obesity. Central obesity, especially abdominal obesity, waist circumference is a key component of metabolic syndrome. Hip circumference is not true answer
  2. HDL (High-Density Lipoprotein): HDL cholesterol is one of the lipids measured in metabolic syndrome diagnosis. Low levels of HDL cholesterol are associated with increased risk of metabolic syndrome.
  3. Glucose: Fasting glucose levels or HbA1c (glycated hemoglobin) are measured to assess blood sugar levels. Elevated glucose levels indicate impaired glucose metabolism, which is a hallmark of metabolic syndrome.
  4. Hypertension: Elevated blood pressure (specifically, systolic blood pressure ≥ 130 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure ≥ 85 mm

questions.text:
Based on ABG analysis of a patient admitted to emergency, what is the diagnosis of the patient
pH-7.28
pCO2- 80mm Hg
HCO3- 28 m Eq /L
questions.solution:
To determine the correct diagnosis based on the ABG (arterial blood gas) analysis provided, let's analyze each option:

a. Metabolic acidosis:

  • pH is low (7.28), indicating acidemia.
  • HCO3- (bicarbonate) is elevated (28 mEq/L), suggesting a compensatory response to metabolic acidosis.
  • pCO2 (partial pressure of carbon dioxide) is normal or decreased in metabolic acidosis due to compensatory hyperventilation, but in this case, pCO2 is elevated (80 mmHg), which is not typical for uncompensated metabolic acidosis.

b. Metabolic alkalosis:

  • pH would be high (>7.45) in metabolic alkalosis.
  • HCO3- would be elevated (>28 mEq/L).
  • pCO2 would typically be normal or decreased in metabolic alkalosis due to compensatory hypoventilation, but here it is elevated (80 mmHg), which does not fit metabolic alkalosis.

c. Acute respiratory acidosis:

  • pH is low (7.28), indicating acidemia.
  • pCO2 is elevated (80 mmHg), which is characteristic of respiratory acidosis.
  • HCO3- may be slightly elevated due to compensatory mechanisms.

d. Chronic respiratory acidosis:

  • pH may be closer to normal (7.35-7.45) in chronic respiratory acidosis.
  • pCO2 would be elevated (80 mmHg) as seen here.
  • HCO3- would be elevated (>28 mEq/L) in chronic respiratory acidosis due to renal compensation over time, but here it is within normal limits.

Correct Answer: c. Acute respiratory acidosis

Explanation: The ABG values (pH 7.28, pCO2 80 mmHg, HCO3- 28 mEq/L) are consistent with acute respiratory acidosis:

  • pH is low, indicating acidemia.
  • pCO2 is significantly elevated, which is the primary abnormality in respiratory acidosis (caused by inadequate alveolar ventilation leading to CO2 retention).
  • HCO3- is slightly elevated, reflecting compensatory renal retention of bicarbonate in response to the respiratory acidosis.

Therefore, the ABG analysis points towards acute respiratory acidosis as the correct diagnosis for this patient.

questions.text: Which gene is not involved in dsDNA repair mechanism?
questions.solution:
The multistep mechanism of DNA double-strand break repair includes: Protein or protein complexes that identify DSBs in genomic DNA (sensors), transduce, and amplify the recognized DNA damage (transducers and mediators), as well as the molecules that dictate the ultimate outcomes of the DNA damage response (effectors).

Option A: One of the most common inherited cancer susceptibility syndromes is hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC). This syndrome has been traced to defects in mismatch repair. Human and other eukaryotic cells have several proteins analogous to the bacterial MutL and MutS proteins. Defects in at least five different mismatch repair genes can give rise to HNPCC. The most prevalent are defects in the hMLH1 (human MutL homolog 1) and hMSH2 (human MutS homolog 2) genes. In individuals with HNPCC, cancer generally develops at an early age, with colon cancers being most common.

Option B: Most human breast cancer occurs in women with no known predisposition. However, about 10% of cases are associated with inherited defects in two genes, BRCA1 and BRCA2. Human BRCA1 and BRCA2 are large proteins that interact with a wide range of other proteins involved in transcription, chromosome maintenance, DNA repair, and control of the cell cycle. BRCA2 has been implicated in the recombinational DNA repair of double-strand breaks. However, the precise molecular function of BRCA1 and BRCA2 in these various cellular processes is not yet clear. Women with defects in either the BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene have a greater than 80% chance of developing breast cancer.

Option C: KU70 is a protein that identify DSBs in genomic DNA (sensors).

Option D: Gene encoding ATP is not involved in dsDNA repair mechanism.

questions.text: Reason for hepatomegaly in G-6 Phosphatase deficiency is
questions.solution:
Hepatomegaly (enlarged liver) in glycogen storage diseases, specifically due to deficiencies in enzymes like glucose-6-phosphatase (G6Pase), is primarily caused by the accumulation of substances that cannot be properly metabolized due to the enzyme deficiency. Let's analyze the options given:

a. Accumulation of Glycogen flakes:

  • Glycogen is a polymer of glucose molecules stored in liver and muscle cells.
  • In glycogen storage diseases where there is a deficiency in enzymes like glucose-6-phosphatase, glycogen synthesis is normal but glycogen breakdown is impaired.
  • Accumulation of glycogen (not necessarily in the form of "flakes" but rather as large, abnormal glycogen deposits) occurs within hepatocytes (liver cells).

b. Accumulation of glucose-1 phosphate:

  • Glucose-1-phosphate is an intermediate in glycogen metabolism.
  • In G6Pase deficiency, there is impaired conversion of glucose-6-phosphate to glucose, leading to an accumulation of glucose-6-phosphate.
  • However, glucose-1-phosphate accumulation is not a primary cause of hepatomegaly in G6Pase deficiency.

c. Accumulation of glucose-6 phosphate:

  • Glucose-6-phosphate accumulates in G6Pase deficiency because the enzyme cannot convert it to free glucose.But Glucose-6-phosphate does not store,it diverts for different pathways.
  • This accumulation of glucose-6-phosphate leads to increased glycogen synthesis (glycogenesis) and subsequent storage of abnormal glycogen flakes deposits within liver cells, contributing to hepatomegaly.

d. Accumulation of glycogenin:

  • Glycogenin is a primer protein that initiates glycogen synthesis.
  • Its accumulation is not typically associated with hepatomegaly in G6Pase deficiency.

questions.text: Active site of enzyme is complimentary to:
questions.solution:
The active site of an enzyme is a region where substrates bind and undergo chemical reactions to form products. Let's analyze the options provided:

a. Transition state:

  • The transition state is a high-energy intermediate that forms during the conversion of substrate(s) into product(s) in an enzymatic reaction.
  • While enzymes stabilize the transition state to lower the activation energy required for the reaction, the active site itself is primarily complementary to the substrate, not the transition state.

b. Allosteric activator:

  • Allosteric activators bind to allosteric sites on enzymes, which are distinct from the active site.
  • These activators can enhance enzyme activity by inducing a conformational change in the enzyme, but they do not directly bind to the active site.

c. Substrate:

  • The substrate is the molecule upon which the enzyme acts.
  • The active site of the enzyme is specifically complementary to the substrate molecules that it binds.
  • This complementary fit allows enzymes to catalyze specific reactions with their substrates.

d. Product:

  • The product is the molecule(s) formed as a result of the enzymatic reaction.
  • The active site is not typically complementary to the product because once the reaction is catalyzed, the product is released from the active site.

2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) is a small molecule that binds to hemoglobin (Hb), affecting its oxygen binding affinity. Let's analyze the options provided:

a. Heme part of Hb:

  • The heme group of hemoglobin contains iron (Fe) and is responsible for binding oxygen molecules.
  • 2,3-BPG does not bind to the heme group of hemoglobin.

b. Globin part of Hb:

  • Hemoglobin consists of four protein subunits: two alpha chains and two beta chains (in adult hemoglobin, HbA).
  • 2,3-BPG binds to specific sites on the globin chains (both alpha and beta), specifically interacting with lysine residues.

c. Heme part of myoglobin:

  • Myoglobin is a single-chain protein found in muscle tissue that also contains a heme group.
  • 2,3-BPG does not bind to the heme group of myoglobin.

d. Globin part of myoglobin:

  • Myoglobin, like hemoglobin, consists of a globin chain (in this case, a single chain).
  • 2,3-BPG does not bind to myoglobin; its primary interaction is with hemoglobin.

Explanation: 2,3-BPG binds specifically to sites on the globin chains of hemoglobin, altering the oxygen affinity of hemoglobin. This binding occurs at positively charged amino acid residues within the central cavity of the hemoglobin tetramer, primarily interacting with lysine residues on the globin chains. This interaction reduces the oxygen affinity of hemoglobin, promoting the release of oxygen to tissues where it is needed.

Therefore, 2,3-BPG binds to the globin part of hemoglobin.

Hybridoma technology involves the production of monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) by fusing a specific antibody-producing B cell (from an immunized animal) with a myeloma cell (a cancerous plasma cell). The resulting hybrid cell, called a hybridoma, has the capability to continuously produce large quantities of a specific monoclonal antibody.

Hybridoma technology needs HAT medium, HAT medium, also known as Hypoxanthine-Aminopterin-Thymidine medium, is a selective growth medium used in hybridoma technology and cell culture techniques, particularly in the production of monoclonal antibodies. Here's a breakdown of its components and purpose:

  1. Components of HAT Medium:
    • Hypoxanthine: can enter salvage pathway.
    • Aminopterin: A folic acid analogue that inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, thereby blocking de novo synthesis of purine and pyrimidine nucleotides.
    • Thymidine: A nucleoside that can bypass the inhibition caused by aminopterin by providing a source of thymidine nucleotides, can enter salvage pathway.

So, HAT medium inhibits the de novo synthesis of purines. So, only salvage pathway is operated

the purine salvage pathway supports hybridoma technology by providing a means for hybridoma cells to recycle and utilize purine bases for nucleotide synthesis. This pathway ensures that hybridoma cells have an adequate supply of nucleotides necessary for the continuous production of monoclonal antibodies

Now,

3 type of cells are present in the HAT medium

  1. B cell antibodies- limited lifespan so can grow but limited life
  2. Myeloma/ Cancer cells- can’t grow in HAT medium because it grows only with deno synthesis
  3. Monoclonal antibodies- can grow in HAT medium because can operate salvage pathway

questions.text: In which of the genetic material, Number of Adenine will not be equal to that of Thymine:
questions.solution:
Option A: A bacterial genomic DNA resides inside cells in a highly condensed and functionally organized form called nucleoid. The Escherichia coli bacterial chromosome or nucleoid is mainly composed of the genomic DNA. The nucleoid forms by condensation and functional arrangement of a single chromosomal DNA with some proteins and RNA molecules.

Option B: Mitochondrial DNA is circular, double stranded DNA molecules.

Option C: HIV is retrovirus, containing their genomic material in form of RNA.

Option D: The Herpes simplex virus (HSV) genome is a single, linear molecule of double-stranded DNA approximately 152,000 bp in length.

The chemical nature of RNA differs from that of DNA

RNA is a polymer of purine and pyrimidine ribonucleotides linked together by 3′,5′-phosphodiester bonds analogous to those in DNA. Although sharing many features with DNA, RNA possesses several specific differences:

In RNA, the sugar moiety to which the phosphates and purine and pyrimidine bases are attached is ribose rather than the 2′-deoxyribose of DNA.

The pyrimidine components of RNA can differ from those of DNA. Although RNA contains the ribonucleotides of adenine, guanine, and cytosine, it does not possess thymine except in the rare case. Instead of thymine, RNA contains the ribonucleotide of uracil.

RNA typically exists as a single strand, whereas DNA exists as a double-stranded helical molecule.

Since the RNA molecule is a single strand complementary to only one of the two strands of a gene, its guanine content does not necessarily equal its cytosine content, nor does its adenine content necessarily equal its uracil content.

RNA can be hydrolyzed by alkali to 2′, 3′ cyclic di esters of the mononucleotides, compounds that cannot be formed from alkali-treated DNA because of the absence of a 2′-hydroxyl group. The alkali lability of RNA is useful both diagnostically and analytically.
